Memorandum by the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs.I CIRCULATE, for the information of my colleagues, the Heads of anAgreement reached between the Soviet, Ambassador and the parliamentary under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs about the repatriation of the Baltic seamen.Three separate attempts were made to secure from the Soviet government an assurance that visas required for crossing the territory of the Soviet union would be granted to the British subjects who volunteered to fight for Finlandagainst the Soviet Union and who are now stranded in Finland and Sweden.In this matter it did not, however, prove possible to obtain satisfaction fromthe Soviet Government, and in this respect the bargain suggested by the Cabinet(War Cabinet Conclusions 35 (41) of the 3rd April) has hot proved possible toobtain.In view of the fact that these negotiations have now continued for nearlysix months, and in view of the need for clearing up this question and removingat least one small problem from the path of Anglo-Soviet relations, I have thoughtit better to clinch matters and have so informed the Soviet Ambassador. Mycolleagues will see that the Agreement is made without prejudice to the majorBaltic questions.The Minister of War Transport has made this Agreement possible by hisgenerous attitude in making available and reconditioning one of the Baltic ships.Since reaching agreement with M. Maisky, I have received a telegram fromHis Majesty's Minister at Helsingfors reporting,- on the authority of the FinnishLegation in Berlin, that there is a possibility that the German Government will permit the repatriation of the British volunteers referred to above. If this is confirmed, it should be possible to get them back to this country by sea withoutpassing through the Soviet Union.A. E.Foreign Office, June 5, 1941.Heads of an Agreement reached between the Soviet Ambassador and the Parlia-mentary Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs about the Repatriation of theBaltic Seamen.HIS Majesty's Government undertake to place at the disposal of the SovietGovernment the Steamship Elna, and to have her repaired without undue delay and fitted with accommodation in the shortest possible time.2. His Majesty's Government will pay for the repairs to the ship. TheSoviet Government will pay for the necessary accommodation to be fitted to theship for carrying a large number of seamen.11395 [22595]Printed for the War Cabinet. June 1941.SECRET. REPATRIATION OF BALTIC SEAMEN TO THE U.S.S.R. 3. The Soviet representative will be given permission to visit the dockyardwhere the vessel is lying and to be acquainted with the progress of the repairsnow proceeding on the vessel. The details of the accommodation will be decidedand the execution of the work superintended by the representative of the SovietGovernment. The Ministry of War Transport undertake to give him every possible assistance in the execution of this work.4. His Majesty's Government will take all possible measures to prevent anyimpediment to the sailing of the Etna from, and her returning to, a British porton her first and any subsequent voyage undertaken for the purpose of repatriatingthe seamen desiring to return to the U.S.S.R. It is understood that she willconform to the normal port and navigational requirements.5. The Soviet Government will be given facilities for bunkering the ship and fitting her out with provisions at their own expense.6. The Soviet Government undertake, upon request, to grant with alldespatch transit visas, according to the ordinary procedure, to members of theBritish colony and British merchant seamen at present in Sweden and Finland,unless there be any valid objection in any special case. Following upon the granting of visas, normal facilities for crossing the Soviet Union will be afforded.It is understood that His Majesty's Government will accept responsibility forthe travelling expenses of such persons. The Soviet Ambassador has advised HisMajesty's Government that in any application made by or on behalf of a memberof the crew of H.M.S. Hunter, the said member of the crew shall be described as a "merchant seaman." If this procedure be followed, he has given an assurance that visas will be granted.7. It is understood that the surrender of this vessel is made withoutprejudice to the issues, e.g. the requisitioning of the ships, arising in any settle-ment of the general question concerning the Baltic State ships and assets. It islikewise understood that the present arrangement is made without prejudice tothe attitude of the Soviet Government on the general Baltic question.
